message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Prostate cancer commonly metastasizes to the bones and can cause new-onset lower back pain. Elevated PAP levels and involvement of periurethral zone are indicative of locally advanced but not necessarily metastatic disease. Palpation of a hard nodule on digital rectal examination can indicate the presence of a prostate tumor but does not necessarily suggest metastatic disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Lower back pain is a common symptom of metastatic prostate cancer. Elevated PAP can be seen in local recurrence or metastatic disease but is less specific. Involvement of the periurethral zone and palpation of a hard nodule on digital rectal examination suggest local disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While options A, B, and D may indicate prostatic adenocarcinoma, they do not necessarily indicate metastatic disease. New-onset lower back pain, however, is a common symptom of metastatic disease in patients with prostatic adenocarcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. New onset lower back pain is a symptom commonly seen in patients with metastatic prostate cancer. Elevated PAP can indicate local spread, but not necessarily metastatic disease. Involvement of the periurethral zone and palpation of a hard nodule on digital rectal examination are indicative of local spread, but not necessarily metastatic disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. New-onset lower back pain is indicative of metastatic disease in prostatic adenocarcinoma. Elevated PAP may indicate local progression, involvement of the periurethral zone may indicate early-stage disease, and palpation of a hard nodule on DRE may indicate local progression or early-stage disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated PAP, involvement of the periurethral zone, and a hard nodule on digital rectal examination may be indicative of local disease, whereas new-onset lower back pain may suggest metastatic disease. Therefore, (C) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. While all options may be indicative of prostate cancer, new-onset lower back pain is suggestive of metastatic disease. Elevated PAP may indicate prostate cancer but it is not specific for metastatic disease. Involvement of the periurethral zone and palpation of a hard nodule on digital rectal examination are common findings in prostate cancer but do not necessarily indicate metastatic disease.

We refer to PubMed Health for help. New-onset lower back pain is a common symptom of metastatic prostate cancer. Elevated PAP can be an indicator of prostate cancer, but it is not necessarily indicative of metastasis. Involvement of the periurethral zone and palpation of a hard nodule on digital rectal examination are both suggestive of localized prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, new-onset lower back pain is indicative of metastatic disease, specifically to the spine. Elevated PAP is a marker for prostate cancer but does not necessarily indicate metastasis. Involvement of the periurethral zone and palpation of a hard nodule on digital rectal examination are signs of local disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Elevated PAP and involvement of the periurethral zone are indicators of local spread, while palpation of a hard nodule is an indicator of a locally advanced tumor. However, new-onset lower back pain suggests metastasis to bone.
